Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Power Converters with embedded passive components

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches: The objective of this research is to improve power density in
power electronics, while lowering the economic hurdles keeping students from participating in this
field. The approach is to make efficient switching power converters with frequencies at least ten times
higher than conventional designs with no magnetic materials and small-valued capacitors. Resulting
designs will have all passive components embedded in an inexpensive circuit board.

Intellectual Merit: Recent advances in power density have been mostly due to improved semiconductors
that switch faster but these advances are reaching a plateau when used in conventional circuit
designs. This is due to frequency-dependent losses in semiconductors and in energy storage devices.
This research looks to implement a value-added strategy using inexpensive printed circuit boards by
fabricating all passive devices with conductive traces, transforming the printed circuit board into a
three-dimensional resonant structure. This will eliminate post-fabrication tuning and component variation
while maintaining extraordinary levels of performance at reduced cost.

Broader Impacts: To enhance outreach, educational modules on resonant power converters tied to the
research outcomes will engage students and increase access to this developing field. This coursework is
rarely available to students, specially Hispanic, who will be a particular focus of the proposed outreach.
The program will follow the approach of: dramatically enhance the power electronics curriculum at the
University of Michigan, employ educational outreach to encourage Hispanic students to learn power
electronics, and use low-cost technologies to make the design and fabrication of resonant converters
available to a wider public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated new design techniques to improve the power density of power electronics converters.  We studied ways to fabricate low-cost passive components that can be used in high-frequency power converters. Notably, we developed methods to make resonant power converters in which all the resonant elements consists of simple traces on a printed circuit board (PCB).

We developed design guidelines and computer scripts that can allow students and professionals to make PCB components easily. The cost of PCB manufacturing has reduced dramatically in recent years, which makes the design techniques investigated more accessible. 

One exciting application of this research was the development of a microsatellite electric thruster. Researchers in Stanford develop a power converter with PCB components that generated RF to strike a maintain an electro-thermal plasma micro-thruster developed by researchers at the Australian National University. We demonstrated the feasibility of a thruster design that comfortably fits within a single 1U CubeSat (10cm x 10cm x 10cm). We tested the "mini Pocket Rocket" in a vacuum chamber at near-space conditions. 

The PI incorporated several of the technical outcomes of this research into educational modules and demos presented in graduate and undergraduate courses offered at the offered at the University of Michigan and in Stanford University.  The laboratory demonstration and activities were meant to make power electronics a more attractive field.

Through this research program, several undergraduate students got first-hand experience in the development of RF power converters through Summer research opportunities programs at the University of Michigan and in Stanford. At the beginning of the project, the PI presented technical seminars and initial research outcomes in two Hispanic serving institutions with the goal of motivating Hispanic students to continue their studies in STEM fields. In later stages of the project, and once the PI transferred to Stanford University, this research became of pivotal importance in the establishment of a brand new power electronics research program at Stanford University.
